content.description: This has 40ft of quality tight hands with sharp nubbins. The first bit and the last bit are mungy. The crux is pulling into the crack out of the flaring pod above the tree. It then goes up an easier clean corner. Then it finishes up dirty ledges to the tree anchor. This can be toproped after climbing Eat At Degnans or Walk On By, but it is a separate anchor from either route. Or you could probably scramble around up the gully to the left to set up a TR.
content.protection: Pro up to 3”. Anchor is a tree with slings and 2 rap rings.
content.location: Find the tree growing out of the wall about 10ft up and climb the flaring pod into the thin hand crack. This route is left of Eat At Degnans (and Pohono the Barbarian).

content.description:
Another good climb worthy of stars. Around the corner to the left of Eat At Degnan's is an left-trending hand crack. This leads to a stance on the arete. Next is the crux lieback which can be protected by a good micro-cam or nut. Above, easier face climbing leads to a bolted rap station. The bolts have been newly replaced and are bomber.

This is a well protected lead as long as you know how to place small gear, but it is also possible to set a toprope after leading Eat At Degnan's or one of the routes to the right.

This is a good climb immediately right of Eat At Degnan's. It starts in 3" double cracks and heads up through a section of nice steep hands. Towards the top the crack thins to a seam (with a fixed Lowe Ball) and a crux traverse must be made to gain the crack to the left. A juggy knob right were you need it makes this improbable traverse easier than it first appears. Save a .5" piece to place after the traverse so the second has a directional. Rap from the same tree as you would for Eat At Degnan's.

This is a good seldom climbed crack with jams of all sizes over multiple cruxes.  Starts out wide, then pinches down to tiny as hard moves take you out right.  Begin moving up again through a short cranking crux until the crack opens up to tight hands.  Follow this steep tight hand crack with good quality jams that starts out at 5.11 then get easier (5.10) as you get higher to the anchor. Sweet pitch!
content.protection: Standard rack.  Have a good variety of small gear so you will have a piece in that you feel good about before entering the crux.  Extra #1.75 - #2 friend.
content.location: Just left of the tunnel.  Look for the left facing corner behind some small trees.

content.description: One of the first visible cracks on the cliff. You can identify it by the obvious lieback flake at the top. This would be the crux. The bottom wide cracks are a little tougher than they look and may be a little mungy depending on how much traffic the area is getting.
content.protection: Standard rack plus doubles from yellow tcu to .5 camalot. Maybe some more small pro for the crux lieback flake. As of 4/5/09 this route needed some new slings for the rap anchor.
content.location: One of the first cracks on the north side of the tunnel.

content.description: This is a short but super high quality roof crack. The crux is twenty feet of super overhanging ring locks. If it where longer is would be a super classic but even still it's very enjoyable.
content.location: On the right side of the Wawona tunnel (coming out). Just follow the cliff downhill for about 200 feet.
